official-title.#text: Recognizing the need to improve physical access to many United States postal facilities for all people in the United States in particular disabled citizens.

committee-name.#tail: , and in addition to the Committees on
committee-name.#text: Committee on Oversight and Government Reform

committee-name.#tail: , for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

cosponsor.#tail: ) submitted the following concurrent resolution; which was referred to the

text.#text: recognizes the immense hardships that disabled United States citizens must overcome every day;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and full compliance of the laws;
and other public agencies install power-assisted doors to ensure equal access to all citizens; and

text.#text: pledges to continue to work to identify and rectify the barriers that are preventing all United States citizens from having equal access to the services provided by the Federal Government.
Whereas, in 2012, 12 percent of the civilian population in the United States reported having a disability;
Whereas, in 2012, 16 percent of veterans, amounting to more than 3,500,000 people, received service-related disability benefits;
Whereas, in 2011, the percentage of working-age people in the United States who reported having a work limitation due to a disability was 7 percent, which is a 20-year high;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , was enacted to ensure that certain federally funded facilities are designed and constructed to be accessible to people with disabilities and requires that physically handicapped people have ready access to, and use of, post offices and other Federal facilities;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: An Act to insure that certain buildings financed with Federal funds are so designed and constructed as to be accessible to the physically handicapped

external-xref.#tail: ) (referred to in this preamble as the

text.#text: Whereas automatic doors, though not mandated by either the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , provide a greater degree of self-sufficiency and dignity for people with disabilities and the elderly, who may have limited strength to open a manually operated door;
(referred to in this preamble as the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Architectural and Transportation Barriers Compliance Board

text.#text: Whereas a report commissioned by the

quote.#tail: ), an independent Federal agency created to ensure access to federally funded facilities for people with disabilities, recommends that all new buildings for use by the public should have at least one automated door at an accessible entrance, except for small buildings where adding such doors may be a financial hardship for the owners of the buildings;

text.#text: Whereas States and municipalities have begun to recognize the importance of automatic doors in improving accessibility;

Whereas the laws of the State of Connecticut require automatic doors in certain shopping malls and retail businesses, the laws of the State of Delaware require automatic doors or calling devices for newly constructed places of accommodation, and the laws of the District of Columbia have a similar requirement;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , requires automation of at least one exterior door for all newly constructed or renovated facilities managed by the General Services Administration, including post offices;

text.#text: Whereas the Facilities Standards for the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: concerned a post office or other facility of the

text.#text: Whereas from 2006 to 2011, 71 percent of the complaints received by the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: employs approximately 522,000 people, making it the second-largest civilian employer in the United States;

text.#text: Whereas approximately 3,200,000 people visit 1 of the 31,857 post offices in the United States each day; and

Whereas the United States was founded on principles of equality and freedom, and these principles require that all people, including people with disabilities, are able to engage as equal members of society: Now, therefore, be it

{http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/}title.#text: 113 HCON 67 IH: Recognizing the need to improve physical access to many United States postal facilities for all people in the United States in particular disabled citizens.
